awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS+X:RES: Collaborative Research: Creating Inference from Machine Learned and Science Based Generative Models
awd_abstract_narration:
In many scientific disciplines computational simulations are used to enhance our understanding of physical processes of complex systems. In all such simulations simplifications are required to make the problem tractable, limiting the scope of the questions that can be addressed. Generally, computational simulations of large systems with many interacting components, based on the governing physics, requires complex and time consuming computations. This project will apply deep learning neural networks (NN) with geometric transformations based on the physics of the system to accurately approximate traditional physics-based computational simulations in a highly efficient manner. The increased efficiency imparted by the  NN model will facilitate the asking of scientific questions which are currently computationally intractable. While the proposed work will focus on using this method to discover new strain-induced polar phases and phase competition, and to understand the large-scale structure in the universe, the concepts developed in this work can be applied to computational simulations in other scientific disciplines.

The proposed work will focus on the development of foundational data science methods and the application of these methods to augment computationally-expensive science-based generative models in a way that is principled and efficient, thereby enabling improved data-driven scientific inference. The work will place specific emphasis on the design of neural network models, which through physically-significant domain architectures can approximate N-body and highly-correlated phenomena with minimal loss of information. The work will develop tools to guide the discovery and experimental synthesis of new strain-induced polar phases and phase competition, which exhibit enhanced electromechanical responses; and it will expand our simulation capabilities and understanding of the large-scale structure in the universe. Ultimately, this work will provide both domain specific advances, as well as a framework for other domain areas to augment computationally intensive, highly-correlated, N-body problems with data-driven models, which respect the physics of the problem and lead to increased computational efficiency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this program, we collaboratively developed foundational data science methods to augment computationally-expensive science-based generative models. We are explicitly targeting highly correlated N-body problems essential to understanding the universe's large-scale structure and synthesizing and understanding strain-induced polar phases. We made domain-specific advances in cosmology and materials science and a framework for other domains to apply data-driven approaches to augment computationally expensive physics-based generative models of highly correlated N-body problems with data-driven models.

We made a number of critical findings including: 1. For precision scientific experiments data-driven models are not enough, significant improvement can be achieved by including hard-physics constraints. 2. When adding hard-physics constraints, optimization becomes more challenging; thus, improved second-order optimizers can improve outcomes. 3. Neural networks provide a powerful approach to statistically disentangle features from high-dimensional multimodal imaging. This can accelerate information extraction through generative models. The key challenge is designing regularization strategies to disentangle features while still having descriptive generative models. 4. Conventional neural network architectures cannot learn concepts of order, symmetry, and periodicity – this creates inherent challenges in understanding physical systems from materials science to cosmology, where symmetry is a key descriptor.

The outcomes of this program are broadly applicable to science and engineering. Generative models of a complex system will be essential to accelerate forecasting and make predictions of N-body systems. Generative models must not only pass the eye test "looking right" but also be numerically correct. Achieving this requires developing machine learning methods that include physical concepts. This could be as simple as underlying governing equations or more complex such as symmetry operators. When physics constraints are applied, neural networks have deep local minimums, rendering simple 1st order optimizers ineffective. This program elucidated the necessity of codesign, wherein physics information, machine learning, and optimization methods are developed to tackle a problem.

From a broad perspective, this program developed datasets, techniques, and tutorials to train the next generation of data-intensive researchers. We supported one (1) graduate student and six (6) diverse undergraduate students and one (1) high school student. We pushed the boundaries of scientific publication and course development by developing and publishing all materials developed as part of this program open source. Finally, from a scientific perspective, the tools developed particularly for multimodal image analysis are broadly applicable from length scales of astronomy surveys (e.g., James Webb Space Telescope) to sub-atomic electron microscopy of quantum materials.
